Fields.DialogueText: Chervona, you've been rather reserved lately.
Reserved, Kapitan? I did not realize.

Fields.MenuText: Is something bothering you?
Come on, out with it.
Yes, reserved.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing that merits discussion.
There's nothing to be out with.
Hmmm.
Chervona, your privacy is your own but I don't want you to feel uncomfortable sharing your thoughts with me.
Kapitan, you know I have voiced doubts about our missions before.
Which I appreciate. We have our orders from Command, but I respect your opinions.
No one likes constant complaining. I am trying to refrain.
Well, don't. Your heart's in the right place when it comes to our mission and the crew.
Hmmm.
Enough with the preface. What's up?
Kapitan, I believe this mission is a waste of our time. Just short of immoral.
*ALARM*
We'll have to discuss this later.
Later I'd planned to assist in the infirmary.
Much later, then.
@BATTLE
I thought I'd find you in the infirmary.
Protecting merchant shipping is all well and good. It's the lifeblood of your economies... misguided though some may be.
We can debate the merits and demerits of capitalism when you're not dressing a wound.
I can speak with blood on my hands. I have seen the manifests. Supplies? No, the cargo is predominantly wealth and luxuries.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't realize. Where did you get the manifests?
Really? Wait, how did you see the manifests?
I saw the manifests. Your point?

Fields.DialogueText: I submitted a request the moment we were assigned.
I requested them upon assignment.
It's deplorable, is my point.
You have issues with luxury?
There are people, good people, who are cold, hungry, scared. Who is sent to protect them? No one.
And yet we send a fleet to protect perfume and gold.
*ALARM*
Neither of which the people can eat.
I understand your concern. This isn't a mission fit for a Belle of your abilities.
Then will you join me in submitting a formal complaint?
@BATTLE
My crew is as much a part of me as my hull or my guns. If they need tending to, there shall I be.
You're doing good work. Now, you mentioned that you thought our mission wasn't strategically valuable?
Even here we have Morganas to fight. Let's clear them out first.
Why don't you submit the complaint yourself, Chervona?
I am the ship, Kapitan. I can only speak for myself. Command sets the task for you, and I assist.
*ALARM*
Don't sell yourself short, Chervona. You were invaluable against the mutineers.
Think it over, Kapitan, while I do what I was born for.
@BATTLE
May I at least submit the complaint to you, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: Well, that wouldn't do much good at this point.
No, you're a little late.
No.

Fields.DialogueText: You could forward it on my behalf.
Late?
Then to whom, Kapitan?
I submitted one after the battle. Our mission's under review.
Thank you, Kapitan. Even if my voice goes unheard, I wanted to at least raise it.
You were right, Chervona. Thank you for sharing your insights. Don't ever feel that you shouldn't.
You have your place in the command structure, Kapitan. Mine is here, encouraging the crew and keeping them strong.
That's exactly why I'd trust you to take command if I weren't able to carry out my duties.
Is that an order?
A promise.
Kapitan, according to the roster, you are off duty soon?
Yes, why?
I would like for you to join me for a drink.
*ALARM*
I will accept no excuses.
Ha, I'd be happy to. Can we dispose of these Morganas first?
Of course.
@BATTLE
If Morganas got to them, this mission is a waste.
Here you are, Kapitan, za zdorovje.

Fields.MenuText: Za zdorovje!
Thank you, cheers.
What is this?

Fields.DialogueText: What do you think?
Have you had this before?
Drink now! I'll explain.
I may have had this before, but I can't quite remember.
Homemade mead. You won't find it in any bottle.
Well, keep it coming, Chervona.
Indeed. Kapitan, I wanted to discuss this with you...
Anything.
When I had my letter from Stalin, you seemed... well, less than excited.
I... well, Chervona, you know I like seeing you happy. He's... you're... well, what do you see in him?
I know what you're thinking, Kapitan. You find it odd that a Ukrainian would place her faith in the man holding her nation's leash.
I'm even more confused that you'd put it so frankly.
It is... difficult to put into words, Kapitan. I am a Belle. No being carries a sense of their home the way we do... its history, its culture, its pain.
I hate to say "call it a feeling." But perspective goes both ways. My homeland has bloomed and bled as part of the Soviet Union. It has bled before. It will bloom again.
Under Stalin.
Or whoever else possesses the will to sow Ukraine's bloodied meadows with the seeds of her future, to inspire a people to a single collective vision. Few humans do.
... I think I'll have another glass of that mead.
For what it's worth, Kapitan, you have the makings of such a person. It is why I chose you.
Thanks. I think.
Kapitan, an unidentified ship has been attacked by Morganas.
One of the supply ships?
Too small. And defenseless, by the looks of it.
It doesn't matter who it is - there may be survivors. Drive off the Morganas and take us to the remains.
Urgently, Kapitan. I have heard ugly things about what Morganas do to their prey...
@BATTLE
Any survivors?
Three people have been brought on board.

Fields.MenuText: See that they have fresh clothes, water and food.
Ensure they go straight to the infirmary.
Who are they?

Fields.DialogueText: The kitchen and laundry are working now.
Already done.
They haven't yet spoken. Shock, Kapitan.
I'll make sure they have quarters and time to rest. Let's give them some time.
Yes. Kapitan... Our mission did not require you to help. This is a good thing you have done.
Chervona, anyone...
With respect, Kapitan, take your compliment. You inspire those around you to selflessness.
Thank you, Chervona. I mean that.
Do we know anything else about the survivors?
Very little. I do not recognize their language, but one of the Japanese crew seems to have an inkling.
That would make sense. We're in the Sea of Okhotsk, and given the ship's size and lack of armament they'd have to be from somewhere close.
I have requested information from Command about our area of operation.

Fields.MenuText: How are they holding up otherwise?
Good, I'm sure they are missing home.
Have they given any indication that they may be dangerous?

Fields.DialogueText: Their color and energy is returning.
If they have a home left.
No, but leave that to me if they do. What I can heal I can bruise.
Terrifying, being adrift. Do we have an idea of how many were on the ship?
Ten, if I understand them correctly.
Seven people...
*ALARM*
Morganas.
Moving to intercept.
Hold nothing back, Chervona.
They're from Japan?
Northern Japan. Ensign Hojo thinks they might be Ainu.
These people have lost their family. It is our duty to punish those responsible and provide a new one.
@BATTLE
Kapitan? You sent for me?
Yes. Come in, sit down.
I am rather busy attending to the survivors, so if...

Fields.MenuText: Yes, you have been busy. Too busy. You deserve a break.
Please, sit, the survivors are in good hands.
Sit down, relax. That's an order.

Fields.DialogueText: I... Thank you.
Fine, if you say so.
Yes, Kapitan.
Now, here is the surprise. The cooks made... I hope I am saying this right... varenyky?
Varenyky!? Yes! I didn't know we had varenyky on board.
I thought I could give back a little to repay you for the work you do.
Have you tried it? What are we waiting for?
*ALARM*
Oh no.
Varenyky are resilient. Cover them and they will keep.
That's a relief. Drive off these Morganas as quick as possible.
They stand between me and varenyky. They are already defeated.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, I may have figured out where the survivors are from. Shikotan Island.
Shikotan? Never heard of it.
There's an Ainu settlement there, both native and relocated from nearby Onekotan. They're fairly insular.

Fields.MenuText: How insular are we talking?
If they're so insular, what were the survivors doing on that ship?
What else do we know about them?

Fields.DialogueText: They have had controlled meetings with outside groups. That's the only way they meet.
Working on that, Kapitan.
Thankfully, we know a lot. Japanese records from the Onekotan garrison are extensive.
It looks like we can go to Shikotan without leaving our supply patrol area.
Should I alter our course?
*ALARM*
Yes, but let's make sure we don't drag any Morganas along with us.
Da. They've been through enough already.
We're to learn as much as we can about their society before we arrive.
@BATTLE
With pleasure! We owe it to our guests... and soon we will be theirs.
Have you learned anything useful about our guests?
Little enough, due to the language barrier. I did learn that their old island was annexed by the old Empire, turned over to Japan, and then left alone until recently.
Really? Why is that?
The island's volcano is active and erupts a rare type of magma, kimberlite. It is rich in rare minerals, including diamonds.

Fields.MenuText: Kimberlite? Never heard of it.
So they established a trade agreement?
So they pay a ransom to the Japanese?

Fields.DialogueText: Neither had I. I suspect that's what drew outside attention.
Relative sovereignty in exchange for goods. That's capitalism for you.
I suppose the Japanese would call it a trade agreement.
That's their environment. What are they like?
Each individual has a role and responsibility to the society. They also have no economy as we would understand it.
Really? So how do they buy food, shelter, all of that?
Capitalist questions. One provides what they can to the community and the community provides everything they need in return.
*ALARM*
Sounds like a people after your own heart.
Makes you wonder why we ever let them go.
@BATTLE
Very funny.
... Ni, Kapitan. It sounded funnier in my head. Let's get back to business.
Chervona, what is this about the survivors wanting to work?
We've determined that they wish to contribute. By giving them clothing and supplies, we've allied with their community, and they want to do their part.

Fields.MenuText: Well, what can they do?
Do they have useful skills?
What do you think?

Fields.DialogueText: Any kind of untrained labor, Kapitan - I do not believe they are particular.
For living and working on an island, doubtless. We would have to treat them as the rawest of recruits.
I think they're disciplined, at least, and eager to help. We have yet to see how quick they are to learn unfamiliar systems.
Well, I'm not sure what we could assign them to without disrupting ship operations.
Very probably custodial or galley work, until we can train them otherwise or they're not our responsibility.
They won't find that degrading?
Quite the opposite. They are aware this is a military ship, with security and specialized systems. They're happy to serve where useful.
If they want to help with cleaning, I have no objection.
I will make the arrangements.
*ALARM*
If there are more suitable jobs, don't hesitate to tell me.
That shouldn't be hard. They strike me as the volunteer type. We could use more like them.
Especially now of all times. That fleet looks ugly...
@BATTLE
Kapitan, we should be within visual range of Shikotan within the hour.
Good. Do the survivors know they are going home?
It's hard to tell, but they should be seeing some familiar landmarks now.
*ALARM*
All too familiar. Alter course and intercept. I don't want to be followed.
Altering and intercepting.
@BATTLE
I'm receiving reports that the survivors have become... unruly.

Fields.MenuText: Unruly? Maybe they are just excited to be heading home.
Because of the Morganas?
Is there a problem at Shikotan?

Fields.DialogueText: It's the opposite.
No, it seems they are upset about Shikotan, Kapitan.
I'm not sure, but they do not appear happy with our course.
Hold off then. Chervona, do your best to figure out what they are upset about. I don't want to be caught in a trap.
I will try again to speak with them. We seem to be making progress... though slowly.
You'd think the immersion would help them learn.
Rudimentary vocabulary for their surroundings, of course. Concepts take longer.
Kapitan, one of the survivors would like to speak with you.
Speak with me?
She appears to have picked up some of our language.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Bring her up after the battle.
I'm a little busy right now.
I'm not sure if I am the best one to delegate, Chervona.

Fields.DialogueText: With all speed.
She does insist, if you could make the time.
She wants to speak with the person in charge.
I'll do my best if you are here to help communicate.
Where else would I be, Kapitan? I have a feeling we will see eye to eye.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, this is Hotene.
It's a pleasure to meet you, I am happy to see you are well.
Captain... No-home.
I'm sorry? Shikotan is not your home?
Shikotan. No! No-home...away.
Chervona?
Either Shikotan is not their home or they do not want to go home.
No go home... please?
Curious indeed...
We need more information about Shikotan, Chervona. Do you have friends in the Soviet Union that can help?
A few. I will reach out to them immediately, though it may take time to get a substantive answer.
I'm in a complicated spot here, Chervona. I can't just keep them onboard.
You believe they request asylum?

Fields.MenuText: They don't want us to take them home. What else would you call it?
Unless I'm missing something, yes.
Yes, but I can't just grant asylum without justification.

Fields.DialogueText: Asylum's more complex than simply wanting to be elsewhere. States and their cumbersome borders...
I also think this. I want to grant it, though this may be beyond our jurisdiction.
And you hope to receive it from the Soviet Union?
In the meantime, we may need to continue on to Shikotan.
Kapitan?
*ALARM*
I need answers, Chervona. If Shikotan is dangerous, we can keep the survivors safe on the ship.
In which case we'll need to solve that mystery ourselves.
Precisely. Let's face these Morganas before we start gathering evidence.
@BATTLE
Morganas incoming.
We'll never make it to Shikotan if the Morganas keep pursuing.
@BATTLE
Hotene is here again. She wishes to speak with you.
Yes, send her in.
Hello...
Hotene. How may I help you?
We home? But no, please.

Fields.MenuText: I understand you don't want to go, but I need to know why.
I need more details. I can't just grant you asylum because you ask.
Yes, home. We need information.

Fields.DialogueText: You'll be safe aboard me.
You can stay here. No need to go ashore.
We need why, Hotene.
Captain, I beg you, do not return us to Shikotan. I officially request asylum for myself and my companions.
Hotene?
I'm going to assume you didn't learn our language that quickly.
I apologize for the deceit. I will explain everything but please, alter your course.
Not with any appreciable speed. We'll make up for it with firepower.
Hotene, first of all-
Done. We're going to steer clear.
Chervona Ukraina, I'm the captain here.
Do not presume to reproach me as you would a child, Kapitan. If you trust only me in only one moment, trust me in this one.
... Very well. Hotene is your responsibility.
She is my guest, and I will treat her as such.
I am not amused by Hotene's deception.
I'm not amused by you going over my head.
Even if it's to save a life?
She was afraid and protecting her companions. She didn't know if she could trust us.
We saved her. She should be grateful.

Fields.MenuText: That can't involve bringing her home?
So we lug her around until the war's over?
From her point of view, we may have wanted prisoners for ransom.

Fields.DialogueText: Apparently not. That makes it our responsibility to learn why.
From each to each. She has a place aboard me as long as she's willing to work for it.
Now you're getting it. What difference would it make if the black ships were awake or asleep?
I suppose Command can't fault us for helping someone in need.
It goes beyond any international maritime law. It's nothing short of our responsibility to our fellow man.
And have you learned anything new from our fellow man?
She claims to have been a prisoner but I'm not sure she means what we think she means.
*ALARM*
Morganas... What about your friends in the Soviet Union?
They should be responding soon. Moving to intercept.
There's always going to be an excuse, isn't there?
Her people have been caught between imperialist interests for centuries. The czars would have had her be grateful for her subjugation. The least we can do is make amends.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, could I trouble you for some postage?
Again, Chervona? What happened to all of yours?
You must ask?

Fields.MenuText: Have you been using all of your postage on Stalin again?
I guess not. Stalin's a busy man, though.
With trepidation.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not. He's a busy man.
What good fortune I'm not writing him.
You'll be pleasantly surprised.
I'll bite. Who's the pen pal?
Some staff at the Mykolaiv Shipbuilding Institute. They're quite taken with me, if I may dabble in pride.
Answering fan mail?
Quite the opposite, Kapitan! They've got some of Stepan Osipovich Makarov's papers there. I've been monopolizing the conversation around them, I admit.
The admiral?
I think I remember reading about him now. It was a mine that got him, wasn't it?
... Da. The less said about mines, the better, Kapitan. The world is poorer and smaller for his loss. To think we sail so close to where he sailed...
Ahem. As for the postage...
I can tell it's important to you. Take what you need from my quarters.
Thank you! I will do so once I honor the Admiral's memory.
@BATTLE
THE admiral, Kapitan! Pioneer of the icebreaker! Explorer of the Yenisei and the Ob! Terror of the Japanese at Port Arthur! Not bad for a humble Ukrainian...
*ALARM*
Kapitan, request permission to return Hotene and company to Shikotan immediately.
What's going on?
They are traitors, that's what!

Fields.MenuText: Traitors? What have they done?
Should we assign them to cells?
Calm down and explain yourself, Chervona.

Fields.DialogueText: They have abandoned their people and left them to suffer.
Unnecessary. All the world's a cell to the coward.
My friends in the Soviet Union responded.
You got an answer from your friends? What's the situation?
Remember the independent nature of society on Shikotan?
I do.
Hotene and her lot have abandoned their people. In search of more profitable uses of their skills, no doubt.
To play devil's advocate, why are they not permitted to leave if they want to?
Hotene was one of only two doctors on Shikotan. She was sent to Moscow and received medical training for eight years.
How did she manage that?
Shikotan paid, in more ways than one. They thought she was to bring modern medicine home. Hotene has broken her agreement.
And the others?
One is a botanist, the other a geologist. They took advantage of their people's curiosity and fled for greener pastures.
It's hard to believe they would risk death just to make some money.
Shikotan has begged the Soviet Union to find them and return them safely home. They are unaware of the betrayal.
This is a lot to take in. Let's think for a moment and then ask Hotene for her side.
*ALARM*
The Soviet Union is aware we have them now. I suspect they will order us to return them soon.
With all due respect, I do not answer to the Soviet Union. Set a course for the Morganas.
Da.
@BATTLE
Hotene, Chervona has explained the situation to me. I want to hear your side but I warn you, do not lie.
I'll know.
Captain... I want to be a farmer.
I'm sorry?
The paradise I'm sure Chervona envisions is a fantasy. When I was six years old, my community dictated my future.
It must have been terrible, being told you would travel the world and become a successful physician.
Having all of your dreams, opinions, and individuality thrown in the garbage? Yes, it was.
Then why did you agree to it? Couldn't they have sent someone else in your place?
And be a parasite? An object of ridicule and disdain? There was no real choice.
Parasite?
Only if she chooses to be.
We may have acted irresponsibly, impulsively. Yes, there are parts of me that are still unsure, but we all yearn for freedom, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I can't make any promises but I will try to help you.
The situation has grown out of my hands, Hotene.
Hotene, I cannot help you.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain, sincerely.
I understand - but please, what can we do?
Captain, please, nothing can be done?
Hotene, if I were you I'd throw myself at the mercy of the people I abandoned.
*ALARM*
Morganas. Hotene, please return to your quarters.
Yes, Captain.
Hotene, a moment.
Yes?
You deserve to know. Three people died of fever recently on Shikotan. Treatable, but there was no one to treat them.
@BATTLE
That's enough, Chervona.
At least the Morganas know the meaning of unity.
Kapitan, do you have a moment?
Yes, what is it?
My conviction is... shaken.
I think we're all having a hard time wrapping our minds around the situation.
I still feel the Shikotan concept of interdependence, valuing the community over individual greed... is admirable.
I agree.
However, the removal of choice, all individuality? I have said that people cannot be forced to make the right decisions. They must be allowed to make their own mistakes.
It does, but enough to abandon the entire community? To leave its people to fever?
It hurt me to hear too. But I can't help but imagine... if I were ordered to be stripped of my weapons, my equipment; to be turned into a fishing boat for the good of the community...
That you wouldn't run away yourself?
Does that make me a coward?

Fields.MenuText: No, of course it doesn't.
I don't know. I'm not comfortable assigning anyone that title at the moment.
From your point of view, yes.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you really believe that?
I have been struggling with that as well.
I thought so.
*ALARM*
Changing course to engage the Morganas.
Right. Chervona, between us, they would have to strip my command before they made you into a fishing ship.
And I would sell my guns for nets before I saw you lose your station.
@BATTLE
Let's agree to do neither of those things.
Have you decided what to do with Hotene and the others?
At this point, the decision isn't mine to make.
*ALARM*
How so?
Let's dispatch these Morganas first.
Happily.
@BATTLE
Command has been informed of the situation and we are on standby.
What do you think they will decide?

Fields.MenuText: They will grant them asylum.
I have no idea.
They may have us return them home.

Fields.DialogueText: And what will Shikotan do?
This is causing severe tensions, isn't it?
And if Hotene refuses?
Whatever they decide, I don't look forward to carrying it out.
Why the delay? Aren't there policies in place for such a situation?
There are, but the Soviet Union is pressuring to keep them.
And Command does not wish to strain alliances.
Exactly.
I feel bad for her.
You do?
I may not agree with her, but it happens again. Her fate will be decided by a committee and her opinion is worthless.
Caught between bureaucracy on one hand and tradition on the other.
Distinction without a difference. One day there will be a new world without want, where everyone can bloom where they are planted.
Until then, they are slaves to the old one.
Chervona, do you ever think people will figure it out?
What's that, Kapitan?
This Shikotan situation has me thinking. On one side, we have civilizations with near unlimited personal freedom but little social responsibility.
And on the other, responsibility to all in the community at the cost of individual freedom.
Right. How can a society implement two contradictory ideologies?
It is not easy, for sure. I do not think anyone has accomplished it.

Fields.MenuText: If it comes down to it, I guess I prefer freedom.
If it comes down to it, I guess I prefer social responsibility.
I don't know what to think.

Fields.DialogueText: And you will be comfortable in a warm home seeing a person freeze outside? You are free to draw the curtains.
Even at the cost of your command, if it were taken? You know this is where you shine.
That is as informed as any of us can be.
What do you prefer?
I have always supported social responsibility. I still do. However, my ideals are as imperfect as anyone's. I just have to have the courage to engage with that.
*ALARM*
I hope there is a middle ground somewhere.
There is. Perhaps we will not find it, but we will make the world safe for others to.
@BATTLE
Chervona, I received our new orders from Command.
And?
Hotene and her group are to be returned to Shikotan at our earliest convenience.
I see.

Fields.MenuText: I don't agree with the decision, but we will carry out our orders.
Regardless of how we feel, we will follow orders.
They made the same decision I would have.

Fields.DialogueText: Did you want to tell them yourself?
Of course. Should I inform them?
As would I, Kapitan. I will tell them.
I'll inform Hotene and let her tell her companions.
I do not envy you.
We are still a ways from Shikotan. I don't intend to tell them until we are close.
Are you worried they may resist?
It's possible. I would prefer not locking them up on their return home.
I will maintain the secret.
*ALARM*
Sometimes I really do wish we were at the front, Chervona. Fighting Morganas is at least simple and straightforward.
How did a couple of warriors like us end up being diplomats?
You can't always be in the place that's right for you. Hotene certainly learned that.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, Hotene wants to speak with you.
Well, it's as good a time as any to tell her she's been ordered home. Send her in.
Captain.
Hotene, I've been meaning to...
Please, Captain, may I say something first?
Go ahead.
I have spoken with the others. We wish to return to Shikotan. We want to go home.
Ha! Fantastychnyy!
Yes, well...
Kapitan...
Right, I'll inform the necessary people. Thank you, Hotene.
*ALARM*
That means Morganas, yes? I'll get out of your way. Thank you, Captain, and you, Chervona. We are in your debt.
@BATTLE
Thank you for that, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean?
Thank you for interrupting me.
Lying might not be the best idea.

Fields.DialogueText: For not telling them about Command's decision.
It's a valuable skill to have.
Maybe not. But the truth wouldn't have helped.
You really think it's a good idea?
Did you see her? She was proud. She decided her own future for the first time.
You're right. It's not my place to take that away from them.
It is no one's place. Especially not with lives in the balance.
I have a dream, Captain. But... but the others do, too. And without me to make sure they're alive to see it, they might not be.
... About that. Chervona-
If you think me a hypocrite, that is your prerogative. I don't pretend not to care for Ukraine's suffering... for the mistakes of her Union.
We all must fight different battles. A nation can weather such storms. An island cannot.
You really believe, don't you?
Better seismic change than stagnation. The greater your collective, the easier it is to make something of the former.
We're in visual range of Shikotan now... Kapitan!
Morganas have already... Chervona, set a course to attack!
Za revolyutsiyu!
@BATTLE
The remaining Morgana are fleeing.
And leaving... little else.
What is left that you can see? Survivors?
I see no one... I hear no transmissions. It appears they were obliterated.

Fields.MenuText: I can't believe it. After everything...
Send out search parties.
Where is Hotene?

Fields.DialogueText: What are your orders?
On the double.
Below decks. She's out of the loop.
Have search parties deployed and report back within the hour.
Not a second earlier.
You have the helm, Chervona. I am going to speak with Hotene.
Vybacte, Kapitan.
The Japanese will be taking over the search on Shikotan.
Do they have an idea where survivors may be?
No, they don't expect to find anyone.
Hotene?
We're to take her and her companions to the nearest port. Japan has agreed to take them in as refugees.
What will they do now?

Fields.MenuText: That's their decision.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't help but think we've wasted our time.
You might want to hear this. I've requested a new assignment for us.
Kapitan?
An assignment at the front, to face the Morganas. Are you with me?
Kapitan! You do not need to ask.
It's no supply convoy, but hopefully it'll do.
I think for now I am at peace with that, Kapitan. It's in our nature to be compassionate, with all the stickiness that entails.
I pray they make the correct one.

Fields.MenuText: They might be relocated again. Who knows?

Fields.DialogueText: It is a cruel world to have to fight for sometimes.

Fields.MenuText: Not our responsibility.

Fields.DialogueText: Not anymore. For better or for worse.
We're a good fit, aren't we?
Two bleeding-hearted fools. I do not regret it. But I have to admit... I do so enjoy making other things bleed.
If you're hinting I should find you some Morganas... well, let's get looking.
